title: Bhagavad Gita Chapter 1: Arjuna's Sorrow on the Battlefield
content:
### Bhagavad Gita Chapter 1: Arjuna’s Sorrow on the Battlefield

The Bhagavad Gita opens not with divine revelation, but with human conflict. Set on the sacred plain of Kurukshetra—a field of dharma (righteousness)—the scene is charged with the tension of an impending war between two factions of the same royal family: the Kauravas, led by the blind king Dhritarashtra’s sons, and the Pandavas, the sons of his late brother, Pandu.

#### The Stage of War

King Dhritarashtra, unable to witness the events himself, asks his advisor Sanjaya to describe what unfolds. Sanjaya, gifted with divine sight, narrates the scene:

> “O King, having seen the army of the Pandavas drawn in military formation, your son Duryodhana approached his teacher Dronacharya and spoke these words…”

Duryodhana, anxious yet arrogant, points out the formidable Pandava forces—marshaled by Dhrishtadyumna, Drupada’s son—and lists the great warriors arrayed against them: Virata, Drupada, Yudhamanyu, Uttamauja, Abhimanyu, and the sons of Draupadi, all “mighty warriors.”

He then boasts of his own army’s strength, protected by the grandsire Bhishma, and names his own champions: Karna, Kripa, Ashwatthama, Vikarna, and others, “all determined to give up their lives for my sake.”

#### The Sound of War

As the two armies stand ready, the air fills with the sound of conch shells—the ancient signal for battle. Bhishma, the Kaurava commander, blows his conch loudly, “roaring like a lion,” to raise Duryodhana’s spirits. In response, from the Pandava side, Krishna and Arjuna—stationed on a chariot drawn by white horses—sound their divine conches: Panchajanya, Devadatta, and others. Yudhishthira, Nakula, Sahadeva, Bhima, and the great archers like Shikhandi and Satyaki join in, until the sound “reverberates through heaven and earth,” shaking the very hearts of Dhritarashtra’s sons.

#### Arjuna’s Crisis

But as Arjuna gazes across the battlefield, his resolve crumbles. He asks Krishna to place their chariot between the two armies so he may see those “eager for battle.” What he sees is not an enemy—but his own kin.

> “There in both armies I see fathers, grandfathers, teachers, maternal uncles, brothers, sons, grandsons, friends, fathers-in-law, and well-wishers.”

Overwhelmed with compassion and sorrow, Arjuna’s body trembles, his mouth goes dry, his bow Gandiva slips from his hand. He tells Krishna:

> “I do not see any good in killing my own kinsmen in this battle, O Krishna. I desire neither victory, nor kingdom, nor pleasures.”

He questions the very purpose of the war:

> “What is the use of a kingdom, enjoyment, or even life itself, when those for whom we desire them stand here in battle, ready to give up their lives and wealth?”

#### The Heart of the Dilemma

Arjuna’s anguish deepens into a profound ethical and spiritual crisis. He argues:

- Killing his own family is a sin, and no happiness can come from it.
- Those driven by greed fail to see the evil in destroying a family and betraying friends.
- The destruction of a family leads to the loss of its eternal traditions and values.
- When dharma is destroyed, the whole family becomes adharmic (unrighteous).
- Women become corrupted, leading to unwanted progeny and the degradation of society.
- Ancestral rites are neglected, and the family falls into hell.

He concludes:

> “It is better to be killed unarmed and unresisting than to fight and kill my own kinsmen.”

With these words, Arjuna casts aside his bow and arrows, sinks into his chariot, and sits “overwhelmed with grief.”

#### The End of the Chapter

Thus ends the first chapter of the Bhagavad Gita—**Arjuna Vishada Yoga**, the Yoga of Arjuna’s Dejection. It sets the stage not for a physical battle, but for an inner one: a struggle between duty and emotion, action and conscience, the human and the divine.

Arjuna’s sorrow is not weakness—it is the starting point of one of the world’s greatest spiritual dialogues. In his despair lies the seed of self-inquiry, and in his silence, the space for Krishna’s teachings to begin.

---
*Om Tat Sat. Thus ends the first chapter of the Srimad Bhagavad Gita, the Upanishad, the Brahma Vidya, and the Yoga Shastra—the dialogue between Sri Krishna and Arjuna, titled “Arjuna’s Sorrow.”*
